results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 32]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

This film shows John and Marie on a holiday in Tasmania. They spend time in Hobart, visit New Norfolk and Port Arthur, and finally Launceston.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 title cards ‘Holiday in Tasmania’, ‘Produced and Photographed by John R. Anderson’
00:01:30:00 Wrest Point Hotel in Sandy Bay, Hobart
00:02:15:00 views from Mount Wellington, Hobart
00:04:07:00 Franklin Square, Hobart
00:05:00:00 plants and flowers on the road
00:06:10:00 the Bush Hotel in New Norfolk, one of the oldest pubs in Australia
00:07:45:00 driving through the snow
00:09:20:00 visiting the ruins at Port Arthur
00:10:45:00 aerial view of city streets in Hobart including the General Post Office
00:13:47:00 Cataract Gorge Reserve in Launceston
00:15:40:00 city street in Launceston
00:15:55:00 a visit to Entally Historic Home
00:16:28:00 Marie looking stylish with luggage and camera tripod in front of a bus
00:17:25:00 on the boat

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 30]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

This film shows life in Ballarat and regional Victoria in the 1950s, including kids’ birthdays, picnics in the park and holidays at the beach. The film is mainly in colour and the last few minutes are in black and white.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 cute baby playing a toy piano
00:01:40:00 a kid’s birthday party
00:03:22:00 kids playing in a band, including banjo, piano accordion, and guitar
00:04:00:00 playing footy in the front yard of a suburban house
00:05:36:00 title card ‘Wayne 1 Year’ superimposed over a baby with a cake
00:06:40:00 baby in a bath tub in the garden
00:08:22:00 picnic at a park with some excellent shots of a 1950s car
00:10:13:00 the family going on ‘Pad-o-lo’ paddle catamarans
00:12:13:00 Marie and friend eating in the car at a park picnic
00:14:15:00 two men in bathers in a sand bag competition
00:16:04:00 nice shot of Marie on the beach in a lovely printed dress and colourful towel over her head
00:16:35:00 John in a suit on a motorbike
00:21:05:00 local boys playing a game of rugby
00:21:28:00 film changes to black and white for a picnic in the park

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 29]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

In this film, we see the Anderson family on holidays, firstly with the kids at a horse riding school and then at a beach house, swimming, playing cricket and fishing.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:08:00 the kids learning to ride horses at a riding school
00:03:57:00 kids on the beach searching for crabs
00:04:10:00 a bucket of crabs
00:05:39:00 one of the boys on a paddle board
00:07:48:00 the girls playing cricket in the backyard
00:09:27:00 one of the boys dancing to a wireless on the patio
00:09:49:00 cooking steaks on a BBQ
00:11:28:00 the kids with a freshly caught fish
00:13:34:00 de-scaling and gutting the fish

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 28]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

This film shows the wedding of John and Marie’s daughter Sharon to Graeme on 15 January 1977, featuring some great 70s fashion.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 title card ‘Graeme & Sharon, St Patrick’s Cathedral, 15-1-77’
00:00:18:00 Marie walking out of the house in a floor-length dress
00:00:49:00 Sharon in her wedding dress leaving the house and getting into the red car
00:02:32:00 some great 70s fashion amongst the guests
00:03:18:00 the married couple being pelted with confetti by her siblings and friends at the church gate
00:04:10:00 Sharon being carried across the lawn
00:04:35:00 on a river cruise to the reception
00:05:35:00 the married couple cutting the cake
00:06:00:00 Sharon and her brothers on the dance floor

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 25]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents scenes from suburban family life in Ballarat and holiday footage from the Mornington Peninsula.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:03:05:00 a child falling over as he kicks a football in a field
00:05:54:00 two children throw a fully clothed person into a swimming pool
00:08:35:00 slow-motion of three children running and jumping into a pool together
00:19:40:00 footage of child water skiing with Sorrento foreshore and the Continental Hotel in the background

description_for_label:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents scenes from suburban family life in Ballarat and holiday footage from the Mornington Peninsula.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:03:05:00 a child falling over as he kicks a football in a field
00:05:54:00 two children throw a fully clothed person into a swimming pool
00:08:35:00 slow-motion of three children running and jumping into a pool together
00:19:40:00 footage of child water skiing with Sorrento foreshore and the Continental Hotel in the background

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 23]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents footage of the day to day workings of a country Victoria cinema –including black-and-white footage of the Mary Poppins premiere in Ballarat – and group sports in rural Victoria.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:22:00 black-and-white footage of Mary Poppins opening at Vegas 70 cinema Ballarat
00:00:45:00 glamorous woman arrives in car
00:01:50:00 the snack stand
00:03:58:00 kids blowing up balloons
00:04:20:00 crowds outside the cinema

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 22]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents holiday footage shot along the Victorian coastline (Portarlington) along with mixed scenes of suburban family life in the 1950s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:08:06:00 Portarlington Post Office sign
00:08:15:00 panning shot of Portarlington Pier
00:08:45:00 woman in 1950s casual wear eating an ice cream in front of a caravan on the beach as she walks toward the camera
00:08:59:00 nice shot on the beach including umbrellas, boat, man lying down and 40s fashion
00:17:31:00 footage of a merry-go-round
00:18:10:00 Christmas tree, children, parents
00:21:28:00 pan across a bay and town with caravan and car in foreground
00:22:08:00 caravan and car in foreground as ship leaves port in the background
00:23:16:00 surfers
00:35:33:00 young girl with miniature Hill’s Hoist toy

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 21]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

The film contains eclectic footage from a family holiday in New Zealand, a Sherbert concert in Ararat, a Dumbo film premiere promotional parade in Ballarat, and some black and white footage of a surburban house being constructed.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:05:42:00 brief tourist shots in New Zealand: hot springs, tehokowlitu-a-tu, memorial gateway, Maori soldiers
00:07:21:00 shot of a drive-in
00:08:04:00 Astor theatre in Ararat; Sherbert concert footage
00:11:23:00 black-and-white footage of house being built
00:17:52:00 Dumbo film promotion in street parade Ballarat

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 20]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents footage of Ballarat in the 1970s and notably the last day of tram service in the area.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:11:43:00 people using 16mm camera filming trams in Ballarat
00:12:50:00 people alighting the Lydiard st tram for the last time on 19 September 1971
00:16:10:00 conductor issuing tram tickets on the last day of tram service in Ballarat

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 19]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents surburban family life in country Victoria along with holiday footage in and around a developing Canberra in the 1950s. It includes some shots of the Prime Minister’s residence, The Lodge.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:27:00 1940s women’s fashion
00:02:09:00 shot of a typical post-war suburban weatherboard home with car in the driveway
00:06:10:00 Christmas with children and their gifts and toys
00:16:10:00 shots from a military air show
00:20:33:00 shot of lounge room and television
00:24:13:00 aerial shots of Ballarat including the drive-in cinema
00:33:33:00 exterior footage of the Lodge and shot of Canberra developing
00:33:16:00 young girl using an old camera over looking a landscape
00:34:34:00 MLC building plaza and surrounds in Canberra
00:35:08:00 shot of old Parliament house
00:35:15:00 shot of the war memorial

Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents surburban family life in country Victoria along with holiday footage in and around a developing Canberra in the 1950s. It includes some shots of the Prime Minister’s residence, The Lodge.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:27:00 1940s women’s fashion
00:02:09:00 shot of a typical post-war suburban weatherboard home with car in the driveway
00:06:10:00 Christmas with children and their gifts and toys
00:16:10:00 shots from a military air show
00:20:33:00 shot of lounge room and television
00:24:13:00 aerial shots of Ballarat including the drive-in cinema
00:33:33:00 exterior footage of the Lodge and shot of Canberra developing
00:33:16:00 young girl using an old camera over looking a landscape
00:34:34:00 MLC building plaza and surrounds in Canberra
00:35:08:00 shot of old Parliament house
00:35:15:00 shot of the war memorial
